description.plain:
Lorenzo Jerald Patterson (born June 16, 1969), better known by his stage name MC Ren, is an American rapper and songwriter from Compton. He began his career as a member of the controversial rap group N.W.A in 1987, and had a strong presence on both Straight Outta Compton and Niggaz4Life. Following the breakup of the group in 1991, MC Ren embarked on a successful solo career.

He released 3 albums and 1 EP on Ruthless Records where he was signed from 1987 to 1999. In 2004 he started in own record label, Villain Entertainment, where he released an album in 2009. Currently he’s working on his second EP titled Rebel Music.

His moniker is derived from his first name (Lorenzo). He used to write alot of the lyrics for N.W.A, and is considered the most underrated member in the group.



Discography


1992: Kizz My Black Azz

1993: Shock of the Hour

1996: The Villain In Black

1998: Ruthless For Life

2009: Renincarnated

2017: Rebel Music

songs.full_title: Ruthless For Life by MC Ren
songs.title: Ruthless For Life

description.plain:
The title track and the lead single of MC Ren’s third album – “Ruthless For Life” – is a tribute to his friend, the late rapper Eazy-E.

It was produced by L.T. Hutton, who became the head produced of Ruthless Records in 1997. All thought Ren had bigger hits chart wise, this arguably become MC Ren’s most well known song.

songs.full_title: Same Old Shit by MC Ren
songs.title: Same Old Shit

description.plain:
Track 2 and lead single of MC Ren’s debut studio album Shock of the Hour – “Same Ol' Shit” – follows MC Ren in the gritty streets of Compton as he describes a typical day in the hood, including relationships problems, gambling, gunplay and gang rivalry.

Unlike MC Ren’s previous songs it strips away any pretense of glamour around the gangsta lifestyle and outlines the brutality, paranoia and violence at its core.

songs.full_title: Who In The Fuck by MC Ren (Ft. 8Ball & MJG)
songs.title: Who In The Fuck

description.plain:
DX: No doubt. Getting back to the music, the next album, Ruthless for Life, featured 8Ball & MJG on Who in the Fuck.“ How did you guys make that happen?
MC Ren: They had this song I heard back in the day called Space Age Pimpin. I was out of town when I heard it, and I remember thinking, Damn, this shit is hard. These niggas is tight. I listened to that song all day over and over and over. I remember seeing their video when they first came out, but I cant remember the name of the song. After I heard that Space Age Pimpin, I was like, Man, I gotta work with these fools.

So I got on the phone, and I told Ruthless to get in contact with Suave House [Records] so I could fuck with Ball & G. They hooked it up, and I went down to Houston, cause thats where Suave House was at the time. We hooked up with the homie T-Mixx, who did the track for Space Age Pimpin. We all just got together and knocked that shit out, and it came out cool as fuck.

songs.title: Mad Scientist

description.plain: “Mad Scientist” is the 4th track on MC Ren’s Villain in Black album and is based on Ren’s time spent in the studio. It is one of the 2 singles on the album. As we know, lab is well-known slang for the studio (that’s why he’s the Mad Scientist, he’s crazy in the lab/studio) and in this masterpiece Ren defies all possible circumstances and everyone opposing him by blowing us away with his amazing lyricism.

songs.full_title: Rebel Music by MC Ren
songs.title: Rebel Music

description.plain:
This song, produced by E-A-Ski was released on March 27, 2014 as the lead single from MC Ren’s upcoming EP “Rebel Music”.

In this song MC Ren raps about the rap game, his status and has a little message to the police. The song clearly illustrats MC Ren’s frustration with the current state of hip hop.



The remix featuring Ice Cube was released on June 9, 2014.

songs.full_title: Do You Believe by MC Ren
songs.title: Do You Believe

description.plain:
Track 9 on MC Ren’s debut album Shock Of The Hour – “Do You Believe” is a two-part song. The first verse mainly question black Christianity considering black history and everything that has happened.

The second verse question interracial relationships. This verse it highly controverisal as MC Ren wants to punish any black guy making friends with white people. This verse also refers to the L.A. riots.

This song is one of the most controversial song of the album as it was charged with racism. MC Ren does not only attack white people, but also any black guy who is disloyal enough to make friends with them.

Track 7 on MC Ren’s debut album Shock Of The Hour – “Mayday on the Frontline” – sets off the theme of the second half of the album, black supremacy. Ren refers to police brutality againts minorities, the LA Riots, the Rodney King beating etc.

This track was also featured on the soundtrack for the comedy film “CB4”.

songs.full_title: Shock of the Hour by MC Ren (Ft. Kam & Laywiy)
songs.title: Shock of the Hour
songs.title_with_featured: Shock of the Hour (Ft. Kam & Laywiy)

description.plain:
The title track on MC Ren’s 1993 debut studio album – “Shock of the Hour” – foresees the nation’s fiery end in an apocalyptic fury enabling black people to finally achieve justice.

Featured on the track are KAM and Laywiy, while the prodcution is handled by Tootie.

description.plain:
Track 6 on MC Ren’s debut album Shock Of The Hour – “You Wanna Fuck Her” – puts MC Ren and DJ Train in the gritty streets of Compton with their dilemmas with women.

In this song specifically, Ren details his experiences with the women he sees; some are prostitutes, and others married to law enforcement — regardless, at the end of the sing, Ren and Train both get rid of of their issues with women, by exploiting and killing them.

songs.full_title: Right Up My Alley by MC Ren
songs.title: Right Up My Alley

description.plain:
Track 4 on MC Ren’s funky debut EP Kizz My Black Azz — “Right Up My Alley” — puts MC Ren back in the gritty streets of Compton.

In this song specifically, Ren details his experiences of alleyway murders, young girls turning to prostitution, police harrasment and gang rivalary. The song ends up with the murder of a rival gang member.

Ren isn’t trying to solve the problems, he is just reporting on them. As Chuck D said, rap music is the CNN of the ghetto and Ren is just reporting what he sees.

description.plain:
Track 5 on MC Ren’s funky debut EP Kizz My Black Azz — “Hounddogz” — puts MC Ren and Chip back in the 80’s when they went to high school.

This funky laid back track, (co-produced by MC Ren himself), tells the story of a young MC Ren when he was trying to make a name for himself. The song later continues when he’s famous and rich, making the old “friend” running back to him.

description.plain: Track 8 on MC Ren’s third album Ruthless For Life — “Shot Caller” — puts MC Ren back in the gritty streets of Compton. Tired of following orders, MC Ren plots the murder of the shot caller. A shot caller is an individual in a gang who has a high status. This person “calls the shots”, but he dosen’t carry it out, he’s already done that role, hence his elevated status.

description.plain:
This song, produced by E-A-Ski, was released on December 29, 2014 as the third single from MC Ren’s upcoming EP “Rebel Music”.

The song clearly illustrats MC Ren’s frustration with the lack of airplay real hip hop gets.



Featured on the song is E-A-Ski protege Redd Tha Rsonist.

songs.full_title: All the Same by MC Ren
songs.title: All the Same

description.plain: This song is the 9th track on MC Ren’s album Ruthless for Life. The album was a tribute to Eazy E’s death. This track however implicitly deals with exposing Jerry Heller and the music industry for how some rappers gain fame and money. In this masterpiece Ren explains how rappers sell their soul.

songs.full_title: Final Frontier (Clean Version) by MC Ren
songs.title: Final Frontier (Clean Version)

description.plain:
“FINAL FRONTIER” is the solo debut single from the EP. “KIZZ MY BLACK AZZ”. This song made small success for MC REN’S album , making it to 80 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles & Tracks and 17 on the Hot Rap Singles, it become one of the MC Ren’s most well known songs.
EP. “KIZZ MY BLACK AZZ” was released in june 30 of 1992 and 2 months later was certified Platinum ,  having reached 1,406,000 copies solds at 2015.
The “FINAL FRONTIER” single released in september 14 of the same year.
